comments.body: IIUC, in the near-term, the API server will expose a subset of the APIs that the kubelet will expose. To start with, the API server and kubelet metrics APIs will be mutually exclusive.

Thinking more about this, I'm worried that this will get confusing, especially if the API server and kubelet APIs diverge any more. I almost wonder if we want separate api groups for each (e.g. `kubelet-metrics`, or maybe just `kubelet` or `node`). On the one hand, we want consistency so keeping them together makes sense, on the other hand it should be clear which is served by which component. Separate groups also prevents reuse of common types across the APIs. Another option would be to prefix kubelet-only types with "kubelet" (e.g. s/pods/kubeletPods/), but this could get messy if we decide to start serving them at the cluster level.

Thoughts?

In the future, I can see kubelet might exposing `derived` metrics, which will help us scale heapster as well. I don't see why we will have two types if the versions match in that case.

Perhaps, we can state the general APIs in the beginning, and then explicitly state which component will be exposing these APIs?
Do you mean in the documentation?

This comment has now been suppressed by the recent rebase :(

Yeah. I mean better documentation could satisfy my concerns. But in general, if we have a need for diverging the data format between the kubelet and api-server, we might have to abandon this idea. Since this is versioned and we are starting in an `alpha` phase, I'd say lets roll with the current proposal, with better documentation. WDYT?

Ok, works for me.

For future reference, if I make changes in separate commits (don't squash) does it prevent github from collapsing comment threads?

Yeah. Multiple commits followed by a squash after LGTM is the recommended
approach for PRs that have lots of comments.

fs usage cannot belong to any containers.

So kubelets would have to have a configuration flag to choose whether to push metrics or not?

In-order for the pull model to work as desired, kubelet needs to expose a versioned metrics endpoint and heapster should have access to all the nodes in the cluster. Then we need API plugins implemented for heapster to serve all the metrics API endpoints. 
To begin with, there will be no flag in the kubelet. Kubelet will only push metrics to API server.
Will this model work for Open Shift?

I'd eventually like a model where the main apiserver could delegate to another apiserver for the implementation of an api group. 

In that case, the metrics apiserver could have an alternative storage backend and/or collection mechanism. A data puller would need to run in the same network as the Kubelets to be practical with respect to bandwidth and auth.

Similarly, we might eventually want such an alternate data path for events.

In both cases, I imagine keeping current state in memory for low-latency, low-dependency serving and then push history to a pluggable storage backend, with graceful handling of outages of that backend. For stats we could probably tolerate data loss. For events, we might want to try harder to avoid it, such as by buffering on local disk.

Similarly, if we used longer history dependent on such a storage backend, we'd likely need to cache and/or eagerly pre-compute decisions made using the history in order to tolerate outages, and maybe even to cut circular dependencies. (Once we have horizontal and vertical auto-scaling, we'll want to use them for almost everything.)

I view analytics and UI use cases as being somewhat separate from the online production usage scenarios.

comments.body: Can we skip putting it in etcd?  Otherwise it will spam the etcd window and logs, I think?  Since it will be recreated within a few seconds, no need to persist it.  Just need some way to do unreliable broadcast from one apiserver to the other replicas?
@vishh can probably answer this better than I can
+1 to @erictune's concern. We can skip etcd completely and handle all metrics data in-memory. We have had several issues with events in the past.

Or optionally, just call through to the underlying location of the metrics
(node today, a metrics store like heapster later)?  It seems like you only
want metrics as a snapshot, and historical / more advanced metrics would be
elsewhere.  That sounds a lot like how we treat pod logs today (we call to
the api server which calls to the kubelet).

## 

Clayton Coleman | Lead Engineer, OpenShift
@smarterclayton what you suggest sounds more like the Poll system - relying on endpoints on each kubelet - rather than the proposed Push system. Both are described in the proposal.

We really need to have parallel api servers (that's a strong requirement
for HA and other issues).  I don't know that a fan-out solution bypassing
etcd is easy to implement (we rejected it in several times in other
places), so that leaves either etcd or a call through directly to the
underlying node.

etcd for now is fine for derived metrics. We'll optimize later.

comments.body: can I top a nodes stats?  what is syntax for that?

+1. That would be useful. 

`kubectl get` should work on these API resources, like like all other API resources:
https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/kubernetes/blob/master/pkg/kubectl/cmd/get.go

One wrinkle is that these are the first subresources we want to display. Probably the syntax should be something like `podmetrics/derived`.

It would be useful to add a general option (--sort=column, -scolumn) to request to sort by particular columns of `get` output. `top` could be an alias for `get podmetrics/derived -w -s2 -s3`.

comments.body:
Since we are seriously considering moving events out of etcd (due to performance reasons), adding a lot of usage-related data to it doesn't sound like the best idea to me (especially since we're targeting 1000-node clusters by the EOY).
IIUC, usage data will not event be read from etcd since apiserver will be serving it from memory. Thus it seems to be that some append-only database would be enough here.
Anyway, what I wanted to say is that we need to be very careful about performance with this change.

cc @timothysc
CC @vishh
https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/11951#discussion_r36163816
The eventual goal is to move events and metrics into a pluggable backend. However, this cannot be done until apiserver supports plugins.
